container-title: are from the University of Sydney. Her publications include the books Old Songs in the Timeless Land: Medievalism in Australian Literature 1840–1910 (2011), Laughing at the Middle Ages: Comic Medievalism (2014), and the edited volumes International Medievalism and Popular Culture

ALISON GULLEY is Associate Professor of English at Appalachian State University in Boone, North Carolina, where she teaches courses in medieval literature and History of the English Language. She is the author of The Displacement of the Body in Aelfric’s Virgin Martyr Lives (Ashgate
note: She has previously published articles on

and has published articles on Old English hagiography and on women’s spirituality in Old and Middle English. NICKOLAS HAYDOCK, Professor of English at the University of Puerto Rico (Mayagüez Campus), teaches courses on medieval and early modern literature, medievalism, film, theory, and pedagogy. He has published Movie Medievalism: The Imaginary Middle Ages (2008), Situational Poetics in Robert
title: Stevens Point, where she teaches courses in medieval and Renaissance literature. Initially trained as a Renaissance specialist, she has expanded her research interests to include medieval literature, the Inklings, and contemporary medievalism

HARRY BROWN is Associate Professor of English at DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana, where he teaches courses in American literature and culture and game studies. He is author of Injun Joe’s Ghost: The Indian Mixed-Blood in American Writing (2004) and Videogames and Education: Poetics, Rhetoric, and Pedagogy

He has also published essays on medievalism in films and videogames in edited collections and previous issues of Studies in Medievalism. LOUISE D’ARCENS is Associate Professor in the English Literatures Program at the University of Wollongong and holds a Future Fellowship from the Australian Research Council
She has also published numerous chapters on medievalism as well as articles in journals such as Representations, Screening the Past, Parergon, and Postmedieval
